title: Weapons and Wealth: Exploring Global Military Spending and the Arms Trade
text:
1 Introduction
Military spending reveals how nations perceive threats and prioritize security. We chose this topic because defense expenditure provides a quantitative lens into shifting global power dynamics and geopolitical competition. Our analysis explores three questions: How does military spending relate to national wealth? What spending patterns emerge among regional rivals such as India–Pakistan and Saudi Arabia–Iran? And how do major conflicts influence defense budgets even in distant states? Using the SIPRI Military Expenditure Database (1949–2024) and Arms Transfers Database (1950–present), we examine the connections between spending, economic capacity, regional competition, and global conflict. Understanding these patterns offers insight into how states allocate power, respond to perceived threats, and shape the broader architecture of international security.
Description of each data set for Shubham’s reference:
rq1_wealth_spending: Country–year panel (1960–2024) focused on the relationship between military burden and economic development. Each row is a country–year with ISO3 code, UN region / subregion / custom region, military spending as a share of GDP (SIPRI, World Bank, and a merged “best available” spending_pct_gdp), SIPRI military spending in constant 2023 US dollars, and World Bank GDP per capita in current US dollars (gdp_per_capita_usd). This is the main dataset for RQ1 scatterplots (GDP per capita vs %GDP on defense), time series of top spenders, and regional comparison graphs.
rq2_arms_races: Country–year panel (1960–2024) focused on military spending and arms imports. Each row is a country–year with ISO3 code, regional classifications, SIPRI military spending as % of GDP (spending_pct_gdp_sipri), SIPRI constant-dollar military spending, and SIPRI arms imports in trend-indicator values (arms_imports_tiv) from the “top importers” arms-transfer file. This is the dataset you’ll use for rival‑pair time series (India–Pakistan, Saudi–Iran, etc.), regional “arms race” comparisons, and for linking spending trends with arms-import intensity.
rq3_conflicts: Country–year panel (1960–2024) designed as a flexible event‑study dataset for global conflicts. It includes the same identifiers and regional variables as above plus both SIPRI and World Bank measures of spending as % of GDP (and a merged spending_pct_gdp), SIPRI constant-dollar spending, and arms imports. It’s intended as the all‑purpose panel for shock/event analyses (e.g. before/after 9/11, the Arab Spring, or the 2014/2022 Ukraine escalations) where you may want to subset by region (e.g. Europe, MENA) or by specific countries and look at level and composition of military effort around key dates.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
This project draws on two main data sources: the World Bank’s World Development Indicators (WDI) and SIPRI’s military expenditure and arms transfers databases. The WDI series on military expenditure as a share of GDP (MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS) and GDP per capita (NY.GDP.PCAP.CD) are compiled annually from national statistical offices, ministries of finance/defense, and international organizations, provided as CSV files with countries as rows and years as columns (1960–2024). SIPRI’s military expenditure database (SIPRI-Milex-data-1949-2024.xlsx) is compiled by researchers who harmonize official budget documents, defense reports, and NATO/UN sources to produce consistent series in constant 2023 USD and as percentage of GDP, updated annually in wide Excel format (1949–2024). The SIPRI Arms Transfers Database provides bilateral transfer values in millions of SIPRI TIVs by exporter/recipient/year. Key issues include missing coverage for low-income or conflict-affected states, country naming inconsistencies requiring ISO3 code harmonization, aggregate regions in WDI that must be removed, and occasional historical revisions that make results version-specific to the December 2024 download date.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis


Code
## Missing value analysis for RQ1 dataset (wealth & spending)

library(tidyverse)
library(readr)

# Ensure output directory exists
dir.create("figures", showWarnings = FALSE)

# -------------------------------------------------------------------
# 1. Load RQ1 dataset (wealth & spending)
# -------------------------------------------------------------------

# Prefer RDS (if created by Clean_data.R), fall back to CSV
if (file.exists("data/clean/rq1_wealth_spending.rds")) {
  rq1 <- read_rds("data/clean/rq1_wealth_spending.rds")
} else if (file.exists("data/clean/rq1_wealth_spending.csv")) {
  rq1 <- read_csv("data/clean/rq1_wealth_spending.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)
} else {
  stop("RQ1 dataset not found. Run Clean_data.R first.")
}

# Keep only analysis variables (drop identifiers when needed)
id_cols <- c("country", "iso3c", "year", "region", "subregion", "region_custom")

numeric_vars <- rq1 %>%
  select(-all_of(id_cols))

# -------------------------------------------------------------------
# 2. Graph 1: Missingness by variable (bar chart)
# -------------------------------------------------------------------

missing_by_var <- numeric_vars %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), ~ mean(is.na(.)) * 100)) %>%
  pivot_longer(everything(), names_to = "variable", values_to = "pct_missing") %>%
  arrange(desc(pct_missing))

print(missing_by_var)


# A tibble: 5 × 2
  variable                    pct_missing
  <chr>                             <dbl>
1 spending_constant_usd_sipri        49.7
2 spending_pct_gdp_sipri             49.3
3 spending_pct_gdp_wb                43.9
4 spending_pct_gdp                   42.6
5 gdp_per_capita_usd                 18.0


Code
p_missing_by_var <- missing_by_var %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(variable, pct_missing), y = pct_missing)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#2c7fb8") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title = "Share of Missing Values by Variable (RQ1 dataset)",
    x = "Variable",
    y = "Percent missing"
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(scale = 1)) +
  theme_minimal()


# -------------------------------------------------------------------
# 3. Graph 2: Missingness over time by variable (line plot)
# -------------------------------------------------------------------

missing_by_year_var <- rq1 %>%
  select(year, all_of(colnames(numeric_vars))) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = -year,
    names_to = "variable",
    values_to = "value"
  ) %>%
  group_by(year, variable) %>%
  summarise(
    pct_missing = mean(is.na(value)) * 100,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

print(missing_by_year_var %>% filter(pct_missing > 0) %>% slice_head(n = 20))
